markdown: Mapzen's routing software Valhalla now offers multi-modal public transport routing. A blog post [introduces](https://mapzen.com/blog/transit-routing/) the product (for customers), a second blog post [explains](https://mapzen.com/blog/introducing-mapzen-mobility/) the technical background.

Mapzen [elaborates](https://mapzen.com/blog/access-denied/) about its routing service [Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla) and how it provides country-specific access restrictions for pedestrians. For this, the library [ Mjolnir ]((https://github.com/valhalla/mjolnir)) is used to create tiled routing data.

Mapzen has [set up](https://mapzen.com/blog/a-routing-engine-of-ones-own/) a Personal Package Archives or PPAs for Ubuntu for its routing engine Valhalla. This makes it possible to install Valhalla with a simple `apt-get` command.

On the occasion of the second anniversary of the routing engine Valhalla, Mapzen [summarizes](https://mapzen.com/blog/valhalla-2.0/) the highlights, introduces the developer team behind it and announces the version 2.0 of Valhalla.

Mapzen will [cease](https://mapzen.com/blog/shutdown/) operations at the end of January 2018. The migration guide [lists](https://mapzen.com/blog/migration/) all projects which will continue existing. According to a [tweet](https://twitter.com/glennon/status/945034576363102208) and the project description, the Valhalla developers are now working for Mapbox (Mapbox already has a routing engine - OSRM).

After Mapbox hired the Valhalla team from Mapzen, most if not all core OSRM developers seem to [have quit](https://github.com/orgs/Project-OSRM/people) their job. However, there is [no official statement](https://github.com/Project-OSRM/osrm-backend/issues/5209) from Mapbox as to whether they plan to maintain both projects in the future.

Ilya Zverev [writes](http://shtosm.ru/all/osrm-vsyo/) ![(ru)](https://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads/2016/12/ru.svg) (automatic [translation](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=EN&u=http://shtosm.ru/all/osrm-vsyo/)) on his blog about the rise and fall of the Open Source Routing Machine, OSRM for short, which Mapbox stopped contributing to after taking over the Valhalla development team a year ago.

... the [vroom-project](https://github.com/VROOM-Project/vroom) on GitHub by Julien Coupey, the open source application to solve the [travelling salesman problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem)? Vroom is BSD-licensed, relies on OpenStreetMap data, and works with OSRM, Openrouteservice, or Valhalla.

ChrisPark [blogged](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/ChrisPark/diary/399647) a Google Summer of Code midterm update for their [goal](https://github.com/orgs/valhalla/projects/1) of reintroducing transit to Valhalla, an open-source routing engine.

[1] Valhalla, a global routing service [hosted](https://valhalla.openstreetmap.de/) by FOSSGIS e.V., is now part of the routing selection (with foot, bike and car profile) on the OSM website. For more information there is a wiki [page](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Valhalla), Simon Poole's [comment](https://community.openstreetmap.org/t/neue-routing-engine-valhalla/7204/12) :DE-s: on the OSM Community forum, and the GitHub [repository](https://github.com/valhalla).

![lead picture](https://weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/651_T_all.png =853x461)

Valhalla - open-source routing engine available on osm.org [[^1^](#wn651_27941)] |  map data  © [OpenStreetMap contributors](https://wiki.osmfoundation.org/wiki/Licence/Licence_and_Legal_FAQ)

Junzhen [published](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/Junzhen/diary/402456) their Google Summer of Code 2023 project's final report on incorporating a landmark-based navigation [system](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla/issues/4037) into the Valhalla routing engine.
Stadia Maps has [published](https://stadiamaps.github.io/ragnarok/) Ragnarök, a browser-based tool for visually inspecting and debugging routes from [Valhalla](https://valhalla.github.io/valhalla/).

Ian Wagner, from [Stadia Maps](https://stadiamaps.com/), gave a [talk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FpyEld_CImo) on using the open-source routing engine [Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla). The talk systematically covered aspects of Valhalla's flexibility through reference documentation and live demos using QGIS and the JSON API.

Robin Wilson has [written](https://blog.rtwilson.com/simple-self-hosted-openstreetmap-routing-using-valhalla-and-docker/) a blog post showing how easy it is to self-host OSM-based routing using Valhalla and Docker, including Python code to process the Valhalla output.

Mark Stosberg [explored](https://urbanists.social/@markstos/112724263301034909) the optimisation of Minneapolis' low-stress bicycle network connectivity using spatial analysis for generating isochrones to measure bicycle travel distances within the network. He described his process using QGIS, JOSM, and Valhalla to create a customised routing network and generate multiple isochrones. The aim is to prioritise segments for improvement based on their impact on overall connectivity.

c6tower(み) [explained](https://qiita.com/c6tower/items/0ff6ca05f76067c0443a) :JA-s:>>>[:EN-t:](https://qiita-com.translate.goog/c6tower/items/0ff6ca05f76067c0443a?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=EN) how to implement a web application for route searching using Valhalla and Leaflet, detailing the setup process using Docker, Python, and OpenStreetMap data, while demonstrating how to perform route searches and visualise the results on a map.

Ellen Poe has [developed](https://blog.ellenhp.me/performant-intracontinental-transit-routing-in-rust) Farebox, a Rust-based [implementation](https://github.com/ellenhp/farebox) of the RAPTOR algorithm tailored for multi-criteria journey [planning](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/raptor_alenex.pdf) on public transit networks. Designed to operate efficiently on memory-constrained devices, [Farebox](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=42413464) is built on top of [Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla), an open-source routing engine that leverages OpenStreetMap data.
